description:
Venue is great - shared with Minna Gallery - so there's art to look at if not otherwise events going on... limited seating makes this mostly a spacious place to absorb, grab and commute. 

Coffee service - very quick especially if you use apps to order ahead and well prepared with gourmet grounds: Verve, Four Barrel, etc. I tried a dirty chai latte (chai with a shot of espresso). Pleasantly surprised with the chai flavor not compromised by added caffeine. Well balanced, smooth, and pre-sweetened.

OCD alert - some people I know complain about that if the seam of the coffee cup is aligned a certain way, coffee can drip into shirts etc. but this cup *actually* has markings for barista to align the sip hole for coffee lids... I guess there are more people who care about this than I originally thought. Personally, I am not particular as to coffee seam/sip hole issues, but I admired the ergonomics of the coffee cup lid. Guess these are the things that make coffee worth $5 :P but at least I feel it better justified with all the extras you get at Red Door versus some other $5 spots in FiDi...!
author: S J.

description:
Our daycare backup options fell through at the last minute so I watched my son for the day and wanted to take him into the city for the morning and afternoon.  We went to Red Door Coffee, a place that I used to frequent quite often for both coffee in the morning and afternoon and drinks in the evening.  However, this last time I went there I was rudely KICKED OUT with my 2 year old son at 845am while having coffee and while my son was mid-bite in his salted caramel donut (which is terrible and sticky, btw).  I was confronted by someone claiming to be the manager that children were not allowed in the coffee shop, because the art gallery is 21 and over.  AGAIN, this was 845am in the morning and everyone was peacefully drinking their coffee or eating whatever pastry they ordered.   I asked him "are you serious? it's 845am" and also "who is telling us to leave?" he claimed it was the Owners of the place.  Everyone started looking at us, what I hope was in shock, that an asshole was kicking out a father and toddler from having coffee and a donut in the morning.  I am hoping that this was just a lapse in this inexperienced manager's judgment and not something worst like being racist, which also crossed my mind.  I tried calling into the establishment a few times and no-one picked up, and only got voicemail, but I hope they see this review and re-think how they approach this next time.  I know for sure that I certainly won't be going here anymore as their COFFEE SHOP is clearly not kid welcoming.  

PS - I was trying to snap a photo of my son eating his donut, but actually caught him looking at the guy instead as he wouldn't even let him finish his bite of the shitty donut before asking us to leave.
author: Kyle I.

description: A solid coffee/bar spot. Came here with my co-workers during our afternoon coffee run. The place is very spacious having a bar in the back as well as an art exhibit on the side. Very friendly staff! I got the maple latte and a donut that was maple with bacon. Weird sounding, but it was great actually. The latte wasn't too sweet or too strong which is the way I prefer it. The donut was great! It had a mix of sweet and salty. Overall, solid spot and I would gladly come back to try some more things!
author: James R.

description: Super cool cafe which turns into a bar at night.  Highly recommend this place to catch up with a friend or just for a meeting.  The place has a art gallery, barista area and a bar.  Its great instead of stopping at starbucks or peets although it is slightly more pricey.
author: Ruchi M.

description:
Red Door Coffee is a cool concept. I love the interior - they have those gorgeous wooden tables! - and the fact that you can go back for a boozy drink in the evening. (This is great for folks like me who generally prefer a capp over beer but have friends who prefer the latter.)

I got an iced latte and was not entirely thrilled with the coffee. It wasn't too strong or weak, I just wasn't in love with the flavor of the beans.

The pizza focaccia looked amazing, however, and was priced right (shocking for SF).

Wanted to like this place more than I did; I'll come back and give it another go in the near future and order a different coffee - this time, a cappuccino.
author: Nic Z.

description: Cute coffee shop located in the 111 Minna art gallery. This place offers your standard coffee options (cappuccino, latte, cafe au lait etc) and some sweet pastries to compliment your beverage. I enjoyed a soy cafe au lait recently and really enjoyed it (it was recommended by the barista). A great spot to come to with a friend or for a work meeting when you want to get away from the office.
author: Mina T.

description:
Super chill vibe when you walk in. People working on their own things, light hip hop in the background and scattered conversations. the location was wonderful, right in the middle of Soma, SF. Close enough from the Westfield shopping center for a caffeine break for a wakeup call from work if you work in FiDi. For me personally it was the need of a wakeup call on a cold Tueday haha. 

I tried the matcha latte, thank god there was no additional sweetness because it would have taken away from the natural flavor of the matcha powder. They actually brush the matcha powder in a cup/bowl like an authentic japanese tea festival! I was very impressed. The effort and time that was put into making my latte is what made it my favorite matcha latte to date! 

They do have a bar, but I didnt get to try it. SO, I wll have to come back and have a taste of their drinks one afternoon! Or maybe get one of their fresh dynamo donuts the next time i get a coffee :)
author: Alex S.

description: Great atmosphere. Awesome coffee. One of my favorite places in the city.
author: Todd B.

description: This location is a coffee shop and also a gallery. Their coffee is Fourbarrel, and I can buy donuts there too. Sometimes their gallery's paintings are cool. However, when I go there, always many people are in line. It might be only me though. Btw, their space is cool. Staffs are kind. I like this space.
author: Yumiko H.

description: Fun little coffee store in a beautiful space: lovely art covers the walls, and the decor is on point. Came for their donuts; salted caramel was what they had when I went. It was sticky and sweet and delicious! Coffee was like any other place though. Great spot to have a coffee chat.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Very cool cafe! I also love the selection of pastries they have. The pastries & donuts are a bit pricier (normal hip-SF-bakery price), but they're totally worth it. 

My favorite is the pistachio blackberry croissant! 
It has the perfect balance of very different flavors: crispy, sweet, fruity, and nutty. Yum!
~~~ UPDATE~~~ 
Seems like they no longer have the pistachio blackberry croissant, but they now have ham and cheese croissant that's also pretty good! The pastry is slightly glazed in between the flakey layers, so it gives you hint of sweetness along with the savory flavors. (It also looks pretty since it has sprinkles of dried flowers and veggies on top :P)
author: Ella K.

description:
I often go to this place to work before dinner. I really like their coffee--strong, rich and smooth. Besides coffee, they also offer a wide range of drinks such as tea, kombucha and some house special drinks. Whenever I don't feel like too much coffee, I get their tap kombucha. It is always really refreshing and cold. 

Around 5 ish, the coffee shop turns to a bar. Sometimes it gets a bit too noisy.

Overall, this is a nice coffee shop in SF to do work. They have good drinks, good wifi and lots of working space.
author: Clare L.

description: I really like the concept of this place - coffee in a really cool art gallery. However, the coffee itself (despite being four barrel) is not all that great - I'm not sure why since I usually love four barrel. The real reason this place is a deal breaker though is the baristas in the mornings - they're rather standoffish and not friendly at all. They also got my order wrong on a couple of occasions which would've been fine if they'd had a better attitude about it.
author: Sam M.

description:
Red Door is one of my go-to spots for afternoon coffee meetings. It has far more character than the standard Starbucks or Peet's and it's location close to my office as well as Montgomery BART makes it an ideal option.

Coffee is only served in the place until 5pm, after which it comes to life as a bar/gallery/event space.

There are many seating options - high-top tables, bar seats, low chairs, benches, tree logs, you name it. There is also cool art around the wall for you to enjoy while sipping on some good coffee.

I usually get a latte or a mocha. I'd recommend this place if you have time to sit and relax. It's not the cheapest and I wouldn't necessarily come here to get a drink to-go.

There is another Red Door Coffee location just a couple of blocks away. I go there sometimes as well but this one is much more interesting.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Red Door
 Coffee

^if you can't see the checks and stars, Yelp is letting us all down, emoji-wise

Literalists go crazy for this place. It's great to have fake business meetings here. The artwork ranges from wack to amazing. Coffee is actually good. Nice enough staff.
author: Will C.

description:
What have I been doing all my life!? 

And by "my life" I mean the 8 years I've been coming to the SOMA area of San Francisco for work and by "doing" I mean "coffee. Coffee, I'm always doing coffee. And it's usually at some average place like Peet's (totally fine) or Starbucks, and it's more of a utility and less of a joy conversion moment. 

However, Red Door Coffee was a joy conversion. Where espresso and milk are frothed and combined to create something not mass produced, but mini-produced. For me. Well. In an art gallery with streaming natural light and big windows and plenty of seating and space to breathe. 

And so for that, I'll be making this a coffee destination on future trips. Great to catch up with a friend, casual business meeting, art perusal, great coffee. 

It comes at an SF price -- $4+ for a latte, but it'll do ya right.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Looking to add cafes to my work rotation so review is based off of that.  

The space is super cool, they have great art on the wall, coffee and.... wait for it.... a bar?!  (like with liquor)

So.... why am I not adding it to my rotation?  There's trendy couches (so great for meeting up and sipping on coffee etc)  But sadly it's not work conducive.  Very few outlets, no tables (well, no chairs, really) & uncertain of wifi reliability.  

Would come back to check out a HH or something though.
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description:
Latest discovery: art gallery and coffee shop. I absolutely adore this idea - it's pure genius.

Coffee:
The latte I ordered tastes good, it's carefully crafted and has a very smooth texture. Most importantly, I liked seeing latte art. They brew and serve Four Barrel Coffee here.

Ambiance:
This is a really nice, clean and calm environment. You can sit back to enjoy a pastry with a cup of coffee. It's a very nice spot to have a conversation or view the artwork on display.

Staff & Service:
Team members on duty were very friendly. Prompt and courteous service, bonus points for this.

Overall, very good experience here. Interested in sipping on coffee while viewing displayed artwork? This is certainly the go to spot for this. Bringing a coffee shop and an art gallery together is truly brilliant.
author: Bennett W.

description:
Nice spot in SOMA for:
- coffee
- working
- catching up with people
- after work HH

Cafe by day, bar by night. It's also an art gallery and apparently a place you can rent out for events. Definitely a unique space worth checking out. 

Coffee is affordable. A regular cup of drip coffee will set you back $3. 

There's outlets and free wifi, making it a good spot to work, but there's more couch/bench seating than table seating so if you're one who likes their laptop on a table, you might have to snag a spot at the bar instead :P
author: Jessie L.

description: I like this coffee shop, because it serves great coffee at a reasonable price, comes with friendly service, a warm, welcoming interior, fun music and some art to look at while sipping on your coffee. I found the atmosphere quite relaxed and casual, so it's become top of mind when asked where to meet for coffee in the city. And if all of that wasn't enough already, it's close to the office, which makes it a perfect quick afternoon getaway. I'm a fan :)
author: Katja S.

description: This is such a cute little cafe. I went to go study there, and they have two long tables (no outlets, or not that I had seen) and then more lounge space with small coffee tables. The artwork was also really cool. The space is clean, bathrooms very clean! There isn't much of a selection of different types of drinks to get but their drinks are tasty! Great space to study, and very friendly staff!
author: Gina B.

description: Good ambience, nice customer service, satisfying food. I went here last week and ordered matcha almond milk latte  and it was scrumptious. Besides that, I would recommend their avocado toast. My time here was pleasant. I definitely will return.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Love this place. It's a mix of all your favorite things in one: coffee, alcohol, good wifi and interesting art. Inviting vibe for those looking to get some work done outside the office. It has that perfect balance of quiet chatter and background music that makes it loud enough to not feel awkward breathing but not too loud to get distracted. One of these days I'll have to try their food. 

Side note: I came here once during work to cry and it immediately relaxed me.
author: Sara T.

description:
As an americano & Croissant expert i have been hunting for the best croissant in the city. I am usually more partial to almond croissants.. however to my initial horror on this fateful Tuesday they only had pistachio...

As it was my birthday yesterday I decided to try something new & broaden my croissant horizons... My first croissant as a 27 yer old would be pistachio - not my usual almond. As someone who considers themselves more a creature of habit this was a bold move for me. But fuck it. It was still a nut. So why not. 

I can confirm- this was the best croissant i have had in San Francisco. 
I should probably mention its only actually the 3rd croissant ive had in SF.. but my quest is just starting...so the bar has been set- watch this space- and thank you red door for unique art & croissant flavors. 

I will be back.
author: Lesley M.

description: I was in and out since I just came here to grab a kombucha (which is on tap), but I just have to take a minute to give it up to their atmosphere and decor. First of all, Red Door Coffee isn't just about coffee, they have a whole bar going up in here. Happy hour anyone? Second, they take reservations. So that happy hour (or coffee club) for a big group? Totally do-able. Their entire interior is decorated with paintings, graphics, and sculptures from local artists. With spot-light lighting, polished hardwood floors and cozy seating arrangements, you get a whole gallery review with your cup of joe (or cocktail). I'll have to drop by again when I'm not in a rush, because Red Door is a breath a fresh air compared to some of the other coffee or bar options in the area.
author: Rebecca L.

description: That have the best Matcha Almond Milk Latte. And the art. Kicks ass. And the music. Smooth like the coffee. It's art meets tech meet drinks. Nice combo
author: Mike M.

description:
This is a REALLY awesome venue. It's definitely not your typical coffee shop. Red Door shares a space with an art gallery, so there is always cool artwork on the walls. The atmosphere inside is very trendy, with natural-looking wooden benches and chill music (not your typical cafe tunes though). 

Despite the amazing ambience and - so my coworkers tell me but I haven't tried yet - good coffee, I really do not enjoy their chai lattes. They are always overly sweet and syrupy, and I can barely taste the milk or even the chai itself. Nevertheless, 4 stars for ambience, convenience, and trust that my coworkers know their coffee!
author: Tiffany P.

description: Red Door is on Minna and 2nd near WeWork. The Americano coffee is a strong pour. This is a big, open café that's excellent for in-person meetings or solo laptop work. Too noisy for Skype calls. The Toast options are new, imported from The Mill. Nice try on the toast but I'd save your bread hankering for somewhere else. Too dry and not enough goodies on too. Like an afterthought. But I'll be back for the rest.
author: Ben G.

description:
They have a great Dynamo Donut selection Tuesday-Friday.  Pick them up early before they're all gone. My macchiato was sour/acidic.  I tossed it.

5 stars for the donut selection.

$10 for a macchiato, donut, and tip.
author: Angelica C.

description:
It was a good cappuccino (I can't really tell a difference between "good coffees" only between good and really bad coffee if that makes sense). Pretty crowded in the morning.

I really like the place itself. Pretty hipster. It's just a red door. I walked right by it!

I've been here at nighttime when it's a bar and I really enjoyed it, too.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Very cool, different, and interesting place to have your coffee chat. Or to just hang out. 

For you coffee lovers - you can find fancy SF hipster coffee here. 
For you art lovers - this is also an art gallery! 
For you alcoholics  - At night this place turns into a bar! 
For you people who just want to do work - there are wifi, tables, and chairs. And food and coffee.
For you people who want to catch up - this is perfect for small and semi large groups  to hang out. 

I believe you can also rent this place out for an event. Probably fits about 200 people. 

Avocado toast is scrumptious! 
Coffee is....fancy coffee in SF overpriced, but delicious. 

EXTRA: The lines for coffee is pretty awful, especially when there are events in SOMA (e.g. Dreamforce).
author: Dana Z.

description: My coffee was screwed up the second time.There was too much milk in cappucino and it didnt taste like coffee at all.Not going to this place again.
author: Prerna M.

description:
My favorite coffee shop but not my favorite coffee. Red door is a coffee shop by day and art gallery / lounge at night fully equipped with a stocked bar and DJ. 

By day: this is one of the best places to do work and not feel like you're working. I worked next door at wework for a year and this was my go to. You can get shit done at a high top Bc they have free wifi and chill house music. 

It's an ok place to take a meeting at baring you can grab seating. If you can't just grab coffee and head to the back room and stand. 

Keep an eye out for the art coming thru here Bc they have some cool stuff on the reg. 

Oh and the coffee isn't bad:) it's good!
author: Will L.

description:
Tucked away in a central part of SoMa, Red Door Coffee is surprisingly spacious and offers Four Barrel coffee, teas, and delicious pastries including Dynamo donuts. It's connected to a gallery with high ceilings, lots of natural light, and rotating art collections on display. 

It's close to our office and a great meeting spot for co-workers or friends. While there's generally a line, it moves fairly quickly and the baristas are always friendly despite the amount of people that frequent this location everyday. There's lots of aesthetically pleasing seating and I especially like the natural wood carved tables and benches. 

The trendy, lively atmosphere makes Red Door Coffee a fun spot!
author: Shira W.

description:
I came in here for a quick cup of coffee, but actually ended up staying longer than I expected. I think the first thing that strikes everyone is how nice of a venue this place is. It has a super wide and open feel and contains an art gallery in a very sleek and modern set up. It's not your typical cafe, and I enjoyed being able to sit tight for a bit to soak it all in. The only issue might be that this place is pretty popular, so it can be tough to find a spot to settle down. 

From what I've seen, this isn't exactly the quietest place, so it might be distracting for work, but bringing over a friend for a chat seems to be great.

Later on, Red Door switches over to being a bar, so there are a lot of drink options available too.
author: Diane J.

description:
Chai latte here is the cats pajamas. Mainly cause they use a mix (and for those obsessed, it tastes very similar to big train). If you try it you'll probably be addicted cause it's sweet and not very chai tasting but super super delicious. 

$3.50 for the chai. Very chill vibes. Will definitely be back, though next time id get it dirty.
author: Steph D.

description: Really nice coffee shop within an art gallery.  Nice scene to have good conversation and we'll brewed coffee.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Art gallery meets coffee shop. 

Beautiful, open space. 

Four Barrel Coffee! 

And a small selection of tasty treats. 

Fast wifi.

Tons of seating.
author: Roopa S.

description: This place was great- recommended to me by some people at an office I was visiting, and it did not disappoint. Quality cappuccino, calm vibe, and the artwork was a nice perk. Lots of creatives sitting around with moleskine notebooks and big ideas. Seems like a good place to catch up with a friend or get work done.
author: Alex S.

description:
Perfect mocha 
Perfect orange citrus chocolate donut
Perfect ambience
Perfect huge work space 
Perfect seating 
Perfect new favorite! 


Oh God, so perfect !
author: Sowmya S.

description: This version of Red Door serves up the same varieties of coffee as their other outpost on 1st/Howard. I'm a huge fan of Red Door's 'Rocket Fuel' cold brew coffee, and I haven't been able to bring myself to get anything other than that.  As everyone's already mentioned, Dynamo Donuts are served here, but there's also the option for toast! The super trendy art gallery makes for a nice working environment, especially on some really beautiful wood benches.  I can definitely see the appeal of not wanting to leave here after sipping on your coffee and donut - it's incredibly soothing!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I continue to be astounded by the lines here.  Do people just not want to pay cash at Special Extra or walk across Market to better places, like Coffee Cultures or the Philz Truck (soon, there will also be a brick-and-mortar Philz AND Blue Bottle)?

The coffee here is not good.  I've tried the Au Lait, the Americano, and a pretty standard iced coffee, and they were uniformly bland, watery, and sometimes slightly burnt tasting.  Furthermore, given the inexplicable popularity of this place, they tend to be way understaffed.  I just waited five minutes, while there was no one in front of me in line, to have my order taken.  

The most irritating thing about this place, however, is its lack of food.  Why even advertise Dynamo Doughnuts if you NEVER HAVE THEM when the afternoon coffee rush rolls around?  (By the way - they only serve them, period, on Tuesday-Friday).  I just moved here from NYC, and our best coffee shops offer similar "fancy" doughnuts, and they have them all day long / consistently buy enough to meet their customers' demand.  If you are so popular and so many people want doughnuts, why not order more?  Once those run out, you MAY be left with toast as an option but, not only does that often run out as well, it's so bland.  It's just sourdough or wheat toast with butter.  No interesting bread varietals.  No jams (at least none of the times I've gone).  I mean, why would you pay a premium coffee shop price for that?

I think I'll continue to add two minutes to my walk (let's be real, I could use it) and go to other, better places on the other side of Market...
author: Tay H.

description:
Dynamo Donuts! They have them Tuesday through Friday, and they have the Mexican Chocolate (vegan) variety. Only thing better would be if they were Pepple's donuts.

Oh, and you know, they have coffee and tea. But really, this is a cool venue to sip your drink and relax. Or a more interesting location to have a businees/coffee meeting.
author: Jon T.

description:
Delicious espresso drinks; can't speak to their coffee - but I'm guessing it would also be good.  The two times I've stopped in I've had an American (one as is and one large with an extra shot of espresso).  Both were creamy, savory, and packed a punch. 

The ambiance in this place is really cool too; I've only done a "stop in and run" - but would be a nice place to relax and enjoy your coffee.  Love the artsy vibe.
author: Rachael S.

description: There's always a line, it's loud, the soy cappuccino is perfectly good. This is a solid spot for people watching, it's spacious, always somewhere to sit.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Great coffee in a somewhat hidden spot. The ambiance here is awesome- super spacious and relaxed, in spite of its busy surroundings. Plenty of table space for doing some work or socializing. Since it's also an art gallery, they're always hosting a collection or two. It's a lot of fun to stop in and see the new art while enjoying a coffee. It can get really busy in the morning and seems to be a magnet for large, corporate groups. The staff is really nice and they do a good job of managing the line.
author: Allison F.

description: If you can snag a blackberry pistachio croissant then get one, no get 10. So damn good. Four barrel coffee is always good. I'm a drip coffee type of guy, but lattes and espresso drinks look great. Price is relatively okay for the area. 111 Minna is a fantastic art gallery and bar at night, but addition of Red Door is definitely welcome. They're my go-to coffee in the morning. I never have service issues because I'm there between 730-8am and it's always pretty empty, but if you're expecting a bubbly, super stoked to be there barista who wishes you the bestest of days...then go to Starbucks. So, service is okay, but who cares, it's not bad and again, the coffee and pastries are on point.
author: Nate E.

description: The donuts this place gets from Dynamo are amazing - especially the maple bacon one!! Make sure you go on Tuesday-Friday, as they don't have any on Monday.
author: Jirayr K.

description:
Best discovery for the month of September! And to think the friend and I just stopped by here because it was right next to the bank (needed to withdraw some $$$) but nonetheless... it was just meant to be!

This place has changed A LOT over the years... the infamous 111 Minna. However, I think, more like, I hope, they stay as is. 

Ambiance / decor: LOVE. Modern yet inviting. Every time I go in, business folks are having a meeting... as they should be because it's nice... open and awesome coffee!

Staff: very friendly and they sure know how to make coffee! Although, I think next visit I might have to tell them to make 140 degrees since it's really boiling hot... 

I have yet to check them at night for happy hour... but it's on the radar!

If you're in the area... definitely... highly recommend it!
author: Cath M.

description: I love the artsy vibes in this cafe, because it is also a gallery! I got a chai latte here, and a chocolate croissant, and the most surprising and delicious curry potato turnover, which I have still been trying to recreate since having breakfast here. The baristas were super chill, and we sorta had our own "intimate" area in broken off seating, covered by hanging dividers. There were cute little wooden stumps as tables as well. Very aesthetic. The bar opens up later in the day as well within the same building.
author: Lola H.

description:
Nice vibe! I love the art gallery, the great coffee, and the not too loud music.
The place is very spacious so even though it can get crowded, it doesnt get too loud. Also, love the availability of bar stools and communal stump chairs.
author: Christina N.

description:
This is my favorite place for coffee in the financial area right now. It's a package deal, the coffee is pretty on point, the space just makes you feel like you can sit and chat and enjoy the amazing stump benches and artwork for hours and that work is far behind you...even though most likely it's around the corner and waiting for you to go back. 

Also, the dynamo donuts always seem to hit the spot. It's a bit pricey, but I always love coming here to catch up with old friends for a break in my day or to start my day. 

The thick toast is overrated in my opinion...it's a bit dry and the jam that I got on it was just okay. Tasted too healthy for me. Also, if you like your drinks hot, make sure to ask for it...they serve it up pretty lukewarm.
author: Annie S.

description: They move at a glacial pace and coffee is overpriced. Good thing it's conveniently located and a pretty space.
author: Amy S.

description: Mediocre chai latte. Even worse pastries. tried to like this place but just couldn't budge.
author: Anthony L.

description:
This review is for the Cafe part, considering this is a bar at night. 

Got there at 12, place was pretty busy, but was able to find seating. Wanted to grab a quick bite and coffee, so I walked up and ordered my semi expensive coffee and there was a toast menu in front of me that literally says "made afternoon and after". So i proceed to order the toast, and then I was told that they stop serving the toast at 11, and so I ask the girl behind the counter why the menu stated that toast is available during afternoon and it was 12:08 and no real answer was given to me. 

Also, as I was sitting around with my coffee, I saw all the bartenders and bar backs start sitting up and and joking around and making obscene comments/jokes and sometimes in Spanish so they don't offend anyone. 

Really not my cup of tea. Not sure how the bar is at night
author: France H.

description:
I've been going to 111 Minna since I first moved to San Francisco.

With their prime location - they've hosted a slew of work related events and social gatherings.

It's never been my favorite venue, but it's always been a solid venue, with rotating art and a decent line-up of unique local happenings.

I first learned about Red Door Coffee last week - when my co-workers decided to pick up some Dynamo donuts for the office. They spoke highly about the cafe addition to 111 Minna - so today I decided to finally try it.

I don't eat sugar or gluten - but a glistening sugary looking pastry called to me from Red Door Coffee's see-through pastry shelfing. I ordered a sticky bun,

The service was friendly and it wasn't too badly priced at $3.00.

The bun was pretty disappointing though.

The flavors were off and I even tried to offer it to a gentleman asking for money in 111 Minna's alley. He kindly refused.

I am sure the coffee is solid here - and I know that Dynamo donuts always delivers - but if you're looking for a sweet fix - I'd suggest skipping the sticky bun. You'd be much more satisfied with one from Specialty's rather than here.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I rave and rave about this place. The menu is minimal but you can't leave unsatisfied with what they do offer: coffee, donuts, and toast. The coffee is four barrel coffee, the donuts are from Dynamo Donuts, and the toast is from Josey Baker Bread (plus you slather jams/butter on top).

I typically grab a small cup of coffee -- no room -- and wheat toast with butter and plum jam. I've only gotten donuts once because I was so excited to see them, but knowing they're there gives me a strange sense of comfort. 

The ambiance is amazing. The furniture is modern but earthy. You get a strong sense of space when you walk in. It feels like a place where you can take a moment to sit and eat your toast without worrying about the wifi password. And of course it also serves as an art gallery so you'll be surrounded with some interesting if not attractive pieces that constantly rotate so you never get too stale. 

I think people complained about service. It's been fine to me. Not perky and cheerful, but not dismissive either -- just calm. I dig it.

So why the missing star? Their set of three menu items is inconsistent. Some days there'll be toast but no donuts, donuts but no toast, and on the worst days no toast OR donuts (the horror!). If they could get a consistent menu going I would definitely give them that fifth star. I'd also not be embarrassed about the three whole times I've invited my coworker to try the toast only to discover they weren't serving it.

Either way, I see this place getting better and I like where it's heading. Kudos!
author: Kathleen L.

description:
Cute, trendy, but overpriced.

It's in the Minna Art Gallery- it's a cool venue, they serve coffee at the bar. Gets busy in the afternoon. Nice place to meet, but if you're just looking to grab a drink, try somewhere else.
author: Sarah G.

description: Beautiful atelier-esque interior with art all over the walls! Coffee is pricey (surprise surprise), but delicious and the wifi is fast. You can choose between low tables at cute little coffee tables or bar stools by the window. Great place to work with accessible outlets.
author: Sophie C.

description: Went here today for a casual work meeting and it was adorable! I'd never even heard of it but my coworker recommended the place. It is connected to an art gallery so the the inside is very well-decorated & trendy and the ambiance is great. It's also not too loud which was refreshing compared to all the other noisy coffee shops in the city. The coffee is tasty--i got the cold brew-- and the wifi is free (and really fast). I will definitely be coming back here to do some work and maybe even try a donut :)
author: Ilana B.

description: Cool ambiance, delicious coffee, supremely uncomfortable seating. If they had nice cushy couches this would be a five (but you'd be unable to get a spot.)
author: Be F.

description: This place is super cute and artsy! I came here intending to get coffee with a friend, but apparently they stop serving coffee and start serving alcohol at 4pm on weekdays. Hey I'm not complaining! We ordered wine and picked seats somewhere near the performance space next door while still admiring the art posted around the cafe. Great place to hang out with someone, though the music can be a little loud. I love that it feels like socially acceptable way to socializing loudly in an art museum. Definitely not your usual coffeeshop. I'll definitely be back, whether for the coffee, wine, or just the company I'm with.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The coffee is pretty good - expensive, but not ridiculous for the neighborhood and quality. I like the (expensive) snacks, the space and its revolving exhibits as well. However, there is something I LOATHE about this place....

The line (or lack thereof)

I don't know what it is about this space but the patrons have NO concept whatsoever how to get in line and progress to the cashier to order. Every time I've been in here it's been a debacle.

And while this should not be Red Door's fault, it actually is b/c their staff does NOTHING to address this. 

This is mostly a tongue-in-cheek review, but the inability to do something as simple as queue/enforce a practice that is widely accepted in commerce really annoys me so sometimes I walk in here and get fed up and leave without ordering anything. I do not understand how they can fail so hard on something so simple.
author: Tmon B.

description:
A smile really helps guys, I'm just saying. This place looks great, with all the cool art on the walls, and is nice and open with plenty of seating. Stumbled upon here by accident, all looked promising so why not?

Well, no smiles. They asked my name, when it was called out the drink was dumped down on the counter and the guy had turned his back on me as I said thank you. It wasn't busy either, no rush, he just needed to talk about his weekend plans y'see ;) Also, I ordered an Americano, and although this drink was nice...it didn't taste like an Americano. I did add cream (always do), so maybe that was just very strong, but usually I can still taste the coffee.

So yeah *shrug*. I'd probably come back and give it another go, as the drink had been nice.
author: Trudi C.

description: I just had a Mocha Latte here but I did like the scene.  It is a combo art gallery + coffee house.  I do like the decor of this place.  The coffee was good and the service was friendly.  I do like to support independent coffee houses from time to time.  The open space and the furniture makes this place a unique place to relax and enjoy coffee and other treats.
author: Lee F.

description:
I just love this place. Coffee shop in the day, bar in the evening - there's always a good time to enjoy this amazing space.

The look and feel of the place is super warm: raw style wooden tables, old public benches, industrial stools, et . Plus, the 111 Mina Gallery (next door) always put on display a bunch of art pieces. I went once when the exhibit was some kind of  "Bosch" style painting displaying some modern topics - that was just the best.

My only concerns is that it closes pretty early. If that's an issue, no worries; just head to Natoma Cabana who's a block away.
author: Simon B.

description:
I love Red Door, as it's basically a concept store where you can have coffee, continental breakfast, cocktails and art all in one space. The space is beautiful, with live edge wood tables and high ceilings, with gallery art on the walls and plenty of seating. 
The wifi is free, the soy cappuncino is great and the space is so relaxing. A great place to catch up with a friend, have a meeting with a coworker, or a quiet after work drink. 
I would warn those who are looking for a quick grab and go coffee on the way to work, this is not your place. The focus is on the coffee, not the speed of service here.
author: Allie D.

description: Bread is from The Mill, Donuts (amazing ones) are from Dynamo. They're cold brew is on tap!
author: Rachel B.

description: Since moving offices to the FiDi I've noticed just about every bar in the area has a little pop up coffee business in the morning. Red Door Coffee is part of the 111 Minna Gallery, with a full bar as well. It's really spacious and the crowd consists of start-uppers, VC's, and suits. The line can get long sometimes, and it can be slow. I've come back to this particular location because they serve Dynamo Donuts nom! I think they also serve Four Barrel coffee, but I'm primarily a tea drinker. Unfortunately for me, their tea selection is: English Breakfast, Chammomile, or Mint and that's it. For this reason, I can't see myself coming here all that often, unless I have a donut craving.
author: Alyssa J.

description:
This is an oasis to avoid the crowd of conventioneers that frequent the SOMA. Typically busy in the morning for the coffee and the bar after work for the yelpers. 
They serve four barrel coffee with precision  and finesse. 
Welcome addition to the neighborhood and two blocks from my office of 20 years.
author: Frank S.

description:
This is a coffee shop in an art gallery!

Their menu was quite simple. I got a soy chai, and it was a great choice. It was a good balance of sweet and spicy. 

The atmosphere is good for either meeting people or doing work. When I went, there was a good mix of people doing both. It was spacious and not too loud. There was plenty of seating on a weekday morning.
author: Aimee Z.

description:
Good coffee, good music, and generally good vibes. Love the old school hip hop playing overhead. This place is located in a art gallery, so that adds to the atmosphere while having your coffee. Now, I'm not familiar with Four Barrel Coffee prior to coming to Red Door, but it was quite good. Ordered a latte and it was smooth and delicious. 

They also have some delectable food items to choose. Mainly donuts as the main takeaway most people get, but they have toast with some great jams on them as well. The day I went there were apple, strawberry, and mandarin orange. That apple is on point with the whole wheat toast. They cut the toast thick for you, so watch out for that. I had no problem with it as the jams can be sweet, so it evens out with the thick cut. 

Overall a great place to hangout and have great quality coffee. Get that toast yo!
author: Sophack S.

description: Red Door has a great vibe appropriate for both work-related meetings and catch-ups with friends. I like that I can hop in for a decent coffee and don't have to second guess whether there will be enough seating options.
author: Meryam B.

description: Very spacious space with comfy leather Benches. Yummiest pastry and almond latte.   a must stop before getting to the office
author: Tony T.

description:
Incredible space for a coffee house, though it's an art gallery and bar as well. Excellent cold brew, single cup pours and espresso pulls for perfect lattes. Snacks are great only if you're in the mood for something sweet, doughnuts are terrific. Not sure if they have any more substantial fare. 

It's such a cool hangout but you're unlikely to get much work done there. On the loud side and great looking patrons are another distraction. Seems a place to see and be seen to a certain extent. Which is cool, just not conducive to productivity!
author: Michael S.

description:
The coffee is good. The sandwiches are too, actually. Here's the problem. It takes them 5 minutes to make a coffee drink. The sandwiches don't show up til 1230. If this were a cafe anywhere but the financial district that might work, but not here. 

On top of that, I just had an encounter with a rude staff person that was so bad, I will never set foot in this place again. I'm actively telling my 250 coworkers about my experience.
author: Scott H.

description:
My coffee obsessed coworker recommended this place to me. I ordered the the cappuccino and was not dissapointed. There was a very nice thick layer of steamed-milk foam that lasted through the lifespan of my drink!

The venue is very nice. From my understanding, the cafe shares space with the Minna Art Gallery, so there are a bunch of works of arts on the wall that you can enjoy while waiting for your coffee.

Pros:
- Strong coffee
- Lots of foam in their cappuccino
- Artwork on the walls

Potential Improvements
- This is not the place to go if you are rushing to grab your coffee. Maybe management can analyze how the service is being done, and make process improvements
author: Jeff M.

description: Hip vibe with great open space and artwork. Staff were courteous and helpful. Try the cappuccino with frothed almond milk. It froths better than regular milk. One of life's simple pleasures.
author: Steve O.

description:
Half art gallery, half coffee shop
Super spacious, good coffee, and nice interior.

I came in here to meet with a friend and was surprised at the size and decor of the place! Red Door Coffee is very well decorated and spacious. It's the first coffee place I've been to that's connected to a small art gallery! They offer free WiFi and Four Barrel Coffee, so it's a nice place to sit down for some work or a casual meeting. It's not too loud either, which is a nice change from the never-ending clamor I find in other coffee shops. I forgot to try the doughnuts, but I'm planning on coming back!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
The pastries look sooo good. I didn't order them. Cappuccino was really good
The lady was nice enough to re make it. Would have like me it hot. Was lukewarm
But too shy to ask for a second remake.
They use great quality stuff including Strauss organic milk ! Awesome !
author: Helper P.

description:
Strauss creamery's barista milk is the best, and in my experience it elevates an ordinary espresso drink to the extraordinary. Blue Bottle beans also help. Neither of these things matter, because their execution was flawed. I asked for a cappuccino, but the result was a latte that is just so-so. Actually, it tasted really watery.

If the A/C weren't set to arctic in here, I might have actually stuck around to enjoy the art and music. The daytime vibe is definitely about tech wheeling and dealing.
author: Patricia D.

description:
I'm convinced this is the smartest business model that's ever existed. I have no idea what the profits are like, but I've been coming to this place ever since they opened their doors as a coffee shop inside 111 Minna Gallery and it's only getting better. They now have cold brewed coffee in a keg, on tap. Yes. Why the hell wouldn't they considering the simple steps they've taken to become a really well-established coffee shop in this city. 

There hasn't been a day gone by that I've applied myself toward a paycheck without visiting this place to spend just a little bit of said paycheck on coffee relief in a comfortable environment. They now churn through a 12 deep line like champs. The next time I come across a private event space, art gallery, coffee shop, bar and meeting space like this, I'll have high expectations and say "tap that cold-brewed coffee keg yet though?"
author: Jon A.

description: Great espresso (nice crema) served with sparkling water. Pretty standard. The space is more suited as the after work bar it is, but fine for a quick morning meeting or quiet coffee
author: Andrew B.

description:
Beautiful and artsy, great spot to have a cup of coffee, stare to the art on the walls and work, if you are looking for a quiet place to work. I came here looking for a place where i could put my laptop down and work for a bit while sipping on a cup of coffee. 

I got coffee and their toast with butter and jam. Loved it! super quiet and comfy, I truly loved the atmosphere here. Even though it is in a busy part of town, it is not as crowded as you would expect but many people come here to grab a cup of coffee before heading to work or in between their work hours.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: Super trendy modern cafe/bar spot.  It is a coffee shop with a full bar and an art gallery all rolled into one. Not many of those around. Even the tables and chairs look like they are part of the exhibit. Beautiful spot, definitely worth checking out.
author: Sunil R.

description: Really cool and hip place for coffee. Love the ambiance and art work surrounding the space. Strong solid coffee and pastries as well.
author: Samantha S.

description: I was so happy to follow the Yelp fairies around the corner from the office to this beautiful space. Opening the unmarked red door and finding ourselves in the sunny looming calm bright gallery space with handsome gentlemen carefully serving up locally roasted brew alongside thick slices of San Francisco sourdough slathered in homemade pear jam just made my morning. The wooden furniture in here is just lovely. The art they were exhibiting at the time wasn't my favourite but that is the way of art I guess.
author: Risa D.

description:
I came here because it's one of the few places where I can get an almond milk latte. It's definitely a cute place, and nice that you can stop by here and hang out for a bit and even get some work done. 

However, I've had much better lattes (almond milk and otherwise). And while this is probably normal, the almond milk is an extra charge, which it's not at my favorite coffee shop in Oakland.

Also, word of advice, don't come here if you're in even a remote hurry. The last few times I've stopped by here close to 9am, it hasn't actually been packed, but the baristas like to chat while they make coffee, which is rather frustrating when I'm trying to get to work.
author: Maria G.

description: Four Barrel coffee at a relatively good price, at $1.85 an 8 oz cup. A bit sour. The other espresso options were standard prices from $2.50 to $4. Did not get any toast or doughnuts since I already had breakfast. Good coffee option in SoMa on price without sacrificing quality. Service quite curt, but they were pretty busy when I walked in. Not a lot of seating. Overall, good, but I wouldn't voluntarily stop here unless I worked close by.
author: Dianna D.

description: Very cool coffee place with a full bar. Their breakfast/brunch items are also very good. I had a piece of sourdough toast that was fresh and very tasty. The place is nice and spacious for a coffee spot too, which it a little more comfortable. I didn't take the time to see where there coffee came from (roasted in house or from somewhere else) but it was great. Definitely worth a stop for a drink if you're in the area.
author: P J.

description:
Coffee: five stars
Space: five stars
Service: 2 stars

The guy manning the counter/register (or whatever we are calling the Square-enabled iPad these days) was engrossed in a loud conversation with his coworkers about some arcane pop culture topic, paying scant attention to customers waiting to order. Pattern continued for at least 3 customers. 

Which guy: black hair, pretty full beard, giant cluster of keys hanging off his belt. Sorry to bother you, man - it's just that you are blowing me and the rest of the people in this line off and impeding our path to Four Barrel nirvana.

Will give it another go, but if that guy is still there I will walk down to Small Foods for the 4 Barrel.
author: Josh M.

description: I was enthusiastic about trying this place on one of my many trips to SFO as I often stay in the SOMA area. The coffee was coffee and the donuts were donuts. Nothing special on the donut front in fact the salted Carmel was a bit tasteless. I was there at 10 am so I don't think the product was stale just unappealing. If you are a donut enthusiast you may want to look elsewhere.
author: J C.

description: This place is super cute! It's an art gallery + coffee shop + a bar at night. It is so close to my office and the perfect spot to have meetings or grab a coffee. This review is focused solely on the coffee shop AKA Red Door. Loved the ambiance! My coffee was okay but they burnt the milk a little bit... No worries though! I'll still be back :)
author: Teresa C.

description: This amazing coffee house is located quite close to mission and 2nd street. It has a unorthodox coffee shop look. There are ample of free space and lot of place to sit down. There is a bar and an art gallery too. The music really sets up a live mood. Good place to hang out with friends for a cup of coffee. This place is really good for a meetup for a large group too.  A little bit difficult to talk due to loud music here. I tried a macchiato and it was amazing. Will definitely come back here.
author: Kunal K.

description: It's kinda hard to see this place in the end of the block. I tried coming here before but ran into a predicament, where there was an event held at the venue. So, I finally came back and decided to enjoy myself. I got the mocha iced coffee which I thought was really good and tasty. Besides the chunks of dark chocolate on the bottom I felt the texture was quite un-smooth and grainy which however did melt in my mouth which gave me a good after taste in my mouth. It is always nice to look at coffee during the day and enjoy I nice coffee. They do have a bar there too where people were getting really inebriated there and saying some humorous things. This man was a foreigner and looked like T.J Miller from Silicon Valley on HBO. A little less fat though lol
author: Kenneth Y.

description:
Today I found out that it's true what my husband says about the Men's Room--it's just as clean as the Ladies'! The women's bathroom was fucked, so there I was.

In a moment of late Friday afternoon fog, I craved coffee and thought of and dismissed getting it at:

Nespresso ($8 bucks for old pre-ground single serving, with weird milk?)
Peet's
Blue Bottle
Roastery

And ended at Red Door. How awesome to enjoy my cappuccino while gazing on interesting art. It was good enough that I begged for a spoon to scoop out the last of the foam. *Minus one star because they don't have any spoons, only those foul wooden sticks.
author: Chiquita y.

description: My new favourite cafe from which to work in SF. Could do with more food. But the bagels are delicious. Very friendly staff. Great location.
author: Paul W.

description:
I gotta up this place to a 5/5 because it's closer to a 5 than a 4, and I hardly give a 5.  The drip coffee has dramatically improved.  Environmentally friendly and healthy is noticed in nearly every aspect of what they do, from compostable packaging to Straus organic milk to local/organic Dynamo Donuts.  What I found interesting is these details are not highlighted anywhere.  For example, they could easily display "We use Straus organic milk" somewhere which I'm sure would bring in business.  Recently I also noticed manual drip cones and a new case to display the donuts.  I also love the music selection and art.  The ambiance is fantastic.  You can't really ask for much more.

Update: They started serving Josey Baker Bread toast a few months ago with toppings like butter, cream cheese, and various fruit spreads by June Taylor.  I was amazed how such simple ingredients put together could be so delicious.  It is one of, if not the best bread I've ever had.

Update 2: Found out the butter used for the toast is by Berkeley Farms, an odd choice considering other ingredients used are from top notch suppliers including Straus, Four Barrel, and TCHO.  Dear RDC, I'd gladly pay an extra 25 cents for higher quality butter such as Kerrygold, or Straus or Organic Valley if it must be local.  Then again, how much can a pat of butter possibly eat into profits?

Update 3: Dear RDC, please dump that nasty bottle of liquid sugar (what is supposed to be "simple" syrup but it's not really simple) for the real stuff.  It has HFCS and preservatives in it which is a stark contrast to your other high quality ingredients.

Update on Update 2: After contacting RDC, the manager switched to Sierra Nevada butter within a few weeks.  Now that's listening to your customers!
author: Nader Z.

description: Nice coffee shop, in addition to good quality drinks you will get nice wood interior.
author: Svetlanko I.

description:
Damn good cappuccino.

In all seriousness, this place is great. The interior design is tastefully done, and the atmosphere it provides is great. The staff was very talkative and nice. The cappuccino was exceptional, and it looks like they have a decently well stocked bar, though seeing as I went at 11am I didn't sample anything from it...
author: Chris M.

description:
Stopped in for coffee on the way to work because a cup of Blue Barrel sounded fantastic. Ordered a soy Gibraltar and a Dynamo donut. For $3.25 I was expecting an amazing drink. Alas, no latte art on my Gibraltar :( I was sad about it. Because really, what is Blue Bottle without latte art?!

I'm still giving it 4 stars because it's a cool place with art on the walls and a nice vibe. Also because I've worked as a barista, and I know how much morning rushes suck. However, people pay top dollar for quality, not mediocrity. Next time, I'll get the full sized latte so I can have my darn Rosetta or heart!
author: Kate L.

description:
Coffee was alright. I got a latte for $4.50 along with a $2.50 donut. They have interesting art and decorations. I mean, the benches are made of some nice looking wood! 

My friend and I walked in for the first time, gave the staff member a big smile and let him know it was our first time at the business! I asked what he recommended and he replied with, "it's pretty basic here, coffee, tea, cocoa. We don't have syrup, and there's toast/doughnuts over there..." THATS IT!? What's your best drink ? What the hell is YOUR favorite drink? I felt like he almost didn't want new customers coming in.. All in all we spent a little over $16 on some "basic" coffee and bread. Never coming back, especially with horrible parking in the area.
author: Antonio P.

description:
I was excited when I found this coffee shop as it is rare to find a place in SF that doesn't burn the milk and destroy the coffee. After going to the coffee shop 3 times I have now decided that I can no longer go there. They need a serious wake up call to being competitive. 

After ordering a triple shot latte (as there coffee is so weak- like Starbucks weak) and asking for less milk (as even the small has too much milk compared to coffee (and is still  too weak) they charged me $6!! $6 for a weak latte that doesn't even match the standard of the worst coffee shop in NY or Internationally.

The staff are also rude here - even when you go out of your way to extra nice to them they act as if they are doing you a favor. These guys need to get real and realize that they are not competitive and I will continue my search for good coffee downtown - watch out SF coffee stores the new players are coming to SF and you will be out of business when you get an education on what real coffee should taste like and what real service is!
author: Jen M.

description: Would love to give them five, coffee is exceptional, service is non-existent. People working there seem lost, very nervous. Probably high turn over. Avoid between 9am and 11.
author: Ian M.

description: Not going to lie I go here for the donuts as quite frankly the coffe is not worth the price. I have not yet been able to tell the pattern in which the donuts show up, and no one that works there seems to know the secret either. I appreciate the vibe they are going for but when your am business is based on the serving of caffinated beverages a bit more focus on customers wanting the caffinated beverage would be nice. Its morning, we want coffee and donuts give us a break if we don't want to wait for you to finish your long winded diatraibe about how the tech industry in san francisco is ruining your vibe. le sigh.
author: Meg N.

description: Closed early. Walked in at 4:50 and was informed that the establishment was closed. Not sure shy they weren't open to stated hours.
author: Maxwell R.

description: To me the macchiato is a bit too sour~ but love the decor and location
author: Katie Q.

description: Coffee is ok, it's four barrel. Atmosphere is cool. But they stop serving coffee and 4 and that is sad.
author: Allison S.

description: This is a Bar not a cafe! Kind of a letdown when we just came back from Europe and went into wonderful places in Paris that the kids could go. We thought this place was a cafe with style. We were rushed out. Bummer!
author: Bill S.

description:
This place doesn't exist, when you call the number it's some art gallery or something and there's nothing at this address except some sign on the door about trespassing and some timeline about something but nothing I could tell that's related to this business moving, closing down, etc....

Report this place as being closed so people don't go there like me only to find out they don't exist!!
author: Arthur Z.

description: The iced coffee was good, but iced chai latte was way better, but the best part is being able to chill in such a unique space with great art.
author: Randy M.

description: For a while I was coming here every day and they even remembered my name, then I decided to start making coffee at home to save $. I love this place, but you can see every SF stereotype waiting in line and sometimes I can barely handle it :). Coffee is amazing. Kinda wish they had some gluten-free snacks but their thick cut toast and donuts look amazing.
author: Turi F.

description: Great environment and location. It is really low key which is part of the charm. It is a part art gallery so that is really interesting too. Sip some coffee and look at some art. They also have a full bar. Don't care to start off your day with some rum in your coffee? You're at the right place. Latte is good and simple. It's my go to place when I don't feel like supporting the giant chain of Starbucks. Support a local great coffee shop.
author: Erica J.

description: Fantastic place.  Great coffee, friendly (!!) baristas that remember you, even if you're not there that often.  Located in a spacious art gallery.  Why people still go to Starbucks is a mystery.
author: Alexander T.

description: Very cool space, and it's hard to not like a place that can get you up (coffee bar) and get you down (alcohol bar).  I love that they have Four Barrel, but the iced coffee is simply not very good.  I'd rather buy a $2 cup of Four Barrel from Super Duper and throw some ice in the cup.
author: Karla R.

description:
Excellent coffee.  Brewed coffee is batched produced with a Fetco machine using Four Barrel beans.  Though I'd prefer individual pourover, this is a very reasonable compromise when you need an excellent cup, fast.  Price is right - $2/cup.  One word of caution -  medium to lighter roasts are the focus here so if you prefer dark roasts (eg Peets, Starbucks, etc), this might not be your style.   Full complement of espresso drinks are equally good.  

Food is rather limited.  Mostly thick cut toast and donuts.

Service is warm and friendly.  No 'tude or pretentiousness.  I felt like a regular on my second visit.

Setting is stylish but grounded.

Highly recommended, especially in SOMA.
author: David C.

description: Adore this place! Excellent coffee, diverse art exhibitions, positive atmosphere with the nicest baristas, not to mention the fact that they accept (also foreign) cards and provide good wifi.
author: Una S.

description: Was really stoked to see a Four Barrel coffee so close to my office at such an excellent venue. Until I tried it a few times to find the baristas have no clue how to make a decent cappuccino. The artisans from Four Barrel should make a point to train anyone using their good name. Until this happens I will walk the extra block to Special Extra and enjoy a properly made Blue Bottle.
author: Matt S.

description: Am a huge fan of this place. Four barrel coffee, Dynamo donuts, and a bar. The space is a welcome reprieve from a coffee chain-filled area of SOMA- the walls are adorned with  colorful art from the gallery, there's tons of open space, and pretty wood tables with fresh flowers. Oh, and v. attractive bartenders.
author: Pria P.

description: This place is delightful. Coffee shop during the day, gallery/event space at night. The coffee is 4 barrel, the guys behind the counter are hot, and the seats are comfy. What more could you ask for?
author: Ruby K.

description: OOoooweeee! This place is pretty. I agree with my leader Jon A. that this is a great place to meet someone else and have options for sitting and sipping.
author: Nicole O.

description: Great space and great coffee. You cannot go wrong with Four Barrel.
author: Nels A.

description: Love the decor and set up instead. Definitely a great place to meet up with your friends to catch up and whatnot. I believe this is a converted art gallery?
author: Michelle L.

description: I've been walking by this event space/gallery for over a year to get to work and was pleasantly surprised when they opened a coffee shop! I've been a couple times and all the drinks I've had (i'm a soy latte kinda girl) have been great, as Four Barrel tends to be! The first time I went right after they opened, they were out of soy which was a bummer but I was fine with a regular latte. It's always quiet and never too busy and there's always seats available. It gets a bit chilly sometimes as they leave the door open but I hardly notice. I'm pretty sure they carry Dynamo Donuts, but I haven't had one yet so I can't be sure (looks like them though). Loving the always changing artwork too!
author: Heather U.

description: They make an amazing almond milk latte here. A bit pricey, but worth it for the quality.
author: Becca S.

description: great baristas and 4 barrel coffee, my co-workers and I come here at least once a day M-F.  I get americanos which are so good I only add a dash of sugar, white top lattes are also great. They also have Texas toast and specialty donuts.
author: Wei W.

description: Nice coffee shop. Not only they make fancy coffee, but there is a feel of community as you see if filled with people. They also have a gallery, which you can enjoy while sipping your coffee.
author: Uncle J.

description: A complete 5 stars in my book. I always order a latte and it's perfect every time! If you are someone who would enjoy having their coffee in beautiful little art gallery, this is the spot. They serve FourBarrel coffee (which I love) & Dynamo donuts too!
author: Victoria C.

description: Part of 111 minna.  It's a combo art/cafe. Wood community tables with lots if seats/tables for meetings.  4 barrel coffee.  Not a great selection of food (donuts and toast).  Great music.
author: around town e.

description: Great open space.  Could use a couple private seating areas. Had some great art the last time I was in, can't wait to go back for a doughnut and iced chai!
author: Shawn B.

description: Great layout, plenty if seating (this is a bar at night). Mixed bag on Baristas - 50/50 -  some are really nice and good at pulling shots, others really loud and off-putting. Chaotic and disorganized when there is a crowd. Personally, Special Xtra is a better place for coffee, but Red Door has seating, Square and Almond Milk, so I hit it sometimes.
author: Justin M.
